page.title: 01Nettlestead to Gt Blakenham
page.content: The land rises sharply from Gipping Valley in east, falling to south, giving wide views eastwards. Soil mostly clay with sandy outcrops much used by Badgers. Farms predominantly arable with some pasture, much the largest being Blakenham Farms (noted garden at Cottage Farm). Many hedges gone, but much tree planting evident, especially on Blakenham Farms. Ditch Wood part of mediaeval Barking Woods, small moated Tarston Hall alongside. Larger noteworthy houses, Nettlestead High Hall, Baylham Hall (both red brick Elizabethan) and Nettlestead chace (early 19th century) with decaying archway remmnant of original tudor house. Several isolated farmhouses and other listed buidings. Population sparse, except in GT Blakenham which has the only shop
